title: 109_hr4490
content:
References in this Act are to the Higher Education Act of 1965. Waivers and modifications are addressed in the Act. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify statutory provisions related to student financial assistance programs in connection with a Gulf hurricane disaster. This includes adjusting expected family contributions for affected students and ensuring institutions of higher education can adapt to the situation. Institutions of higher education in Gulf hurricane disaster areas or serving affected students can apply for the distance education demonstration program, with exceptions noted in reports. SEC. 3. Cancellation of institutional repayment by colleges and universities affected by a Gulf hurricane disaster. The Secretary will cancel any obligation of an affected institution to return or repay funds received for students under various parts of title IV of the Act for cancelled enrollment periods. SEC. 4. Cancellation of student loans for cancelled enrollment periods. The Secretary will discharge all loan amounts under parts B and D of title IV of the Act for affected students in a cancelled enrollment period. Reimbursement will be provided to institutions and lenders for discharged loan amounts. Loan amounts under parts B and D of title IV of the Act for affected students in a cancelled enrollment period may be discharged. Consolidation loans are limited to repayment for cancelled enrollment periods. No refunding of loan repayments is authorized. SEC. 5. TEMPORARY DEFERMENT OF STUDENT LOAN REPAYMENT. Borrowers of qualified student loans or parent loans can defer payments for up to 6 months. Interest accrues differently based on the type of loan. SEC. 6. NO AFFECT ON GRANT AND LOAN LIMITS. Loan amounts for affected students in cancelled enrollment periods may be discharged, with limitations on consolidation loans. Refunding of loan repayments is not authorized. SEC. 6. NO AFFECT ON GRANT AND LOAN LIMITS. Grant or loan funds received by affected students for cancelled enrollment periods will not count against their annual or aggregate limits for receiving grants or loans under title IV of the Act. SEC. 7. TEACHER LOAN RELIEF. The Secretary may waive the requirement of consecutive academic years for qualifying service for teachers affected by Gulf hurricane disasters, allowing them to resume qualifying service by the beginning of academic year 2006-2007. Additionally, there is a provision for expanding information dissemination regarding eligibility for Pell Grants. The Secretary, in conjunction with State efforts, will notify eligible students and parents of their potential eligibility for a maximum Pell Grant through means-tested Federal benefit programs. These programs determine benefits based on income or resources, such as the supplemental security income program and the food stamp program. The Secretary, in conjunction with State efforts, will notify eligible students and parents of their potential eligibility for federal benefit programs like the Food Stamp Act of 1977, school lunch program, temporary assistance to needy families program, and women, infants, and children program. Other programs identified by the Secretary may also be included. SEC. 9. PROCEDURES.

(a) Deadlines and Procedures.--Sections 482(c) and 492 of the Act shall not apply to waivers, modifications, or actions initiated by the Secretary under this Act.
(b) Case-by-case Basis.--The Secretary is not required to exercise waiver or modification authority on a case-by-case basis.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY.

The Secretary's authority to issue waivers or modifications under this Act will end at the conclusion of the 2005-2006 academic year, but existing waivers or modifications will remain valid after that year.

SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. The terms "affected individual" and "affected institution" are defined in the Act as individuals who have received student financial assistance and institutions of higher education located in areas affected by Gulf hurricane disasters. The term "affected student" refers to an individual who applied for or received student financial assistance under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and was enrolled in an institution of higher education in an area affected by a Gulf hurricane disaster on August 29, 2005. The term "area affected by a Gulf hurricane disaster" refers to a county or parish designated for disaster assistance due to Hurricane Katrina or Rita. The term "cancelled enrollment period" denotes any enrollment period affected by a Gulf hurricane disaster. The term "enrollment period" refers to any period of enrollment at an affected institution during the academic year 2005. The term "Gulf hurricane disaster" is defined as a major disaster caused by Hurricane Katrina or Rita. "Institution of higher education" and "qualified student loan" are also defined in relation to the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "qualified parent loan" refers to a loan made under section 428B of title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 or a Federal Direct Plus loan. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
